label: Plate 1
transcription: Pamela is represented in this first Piece writing in her late Lady's dressing Room: her History being known only by her Letters. She is here surprised by Mr. B. who improves this occasion to further her designs.
publication_place: No. 69 in St. Paul's Churchyard, London
source: Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

label: Plate 2
transcription: Mr. B. expostulating with Pamela in the Summer-house after some liberties taken. Mrs. Jervis, who is seen through the Window, having just before left her.
publication_place: No. 69 in St. Paul's Churchyard, London
source: Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

label: Plate 3
transcription: Pamela swooning, after having discovered Mr. B in the Closet. He frighted, endeavouring to recover her. Mrs. Jervis wringing her Hands and screaming.
publication_place: No. 69 in St. Paul's Churchyard, London
source: Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

label: Plate 4
transcription: Pamela having divided her Clothes into three Bundles, in order to leave the House, rejects that containing her Masters Presents, calling it the wicked Bundle, and harangues over her own little Parcel, which she huggs in her Arms; this occasions an exclamation from Mrs. Jervis: Mr. B in the Closet listening.
publication_place: No. 69 in St. Paul's Churchyard, London
source: Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

label: Plate 5
transcription: Pamela setting out in the travelling Chariot for her Fathers, as she is made to believe, tkes her farewel of Mrs. Jervis and the other Servants: Mr. B observing her from the Window by whose private order she is carried into Lincolnshire.
publication_place: No. 69 in St. Paul's Churchyard, London
people: Pamela; Mrs. Jervis; Mr. B; servants
source: Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

label: Plate 6
transcription: Pamela, being now in the custody of Mrs. Jewkes, seizes an occasion as they are walking in the Garden to propose a correspondence with Mr. Williams, in order to contrive an escape, who agree to hide their letters between two tiles near the Sun-flower.
publication_place: No. 69 in St. Paul's Churchyard, London
source: Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

label: Plate 7
transcription: Pamela undressing herself, Mrs. Jewkes being first got to bed, while Mr. B. disguised in the Maids clothes with the Apron thrown over his face, is impatiently waiting for the execution of his Plot.
publication_place: No. 69 in St. Paul's Churchyard, London
source: Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

label: Plate 8
transcription: Pamela on her knees before her Father, whom she had discovered behind the door, having overturn'd the Card-table in her way. Sr. Simon Darnford, his Lady, &c. observing her with eagerness and admiration. Mr. B stuck with his Scene is waiting the Issue.
publication_place: No. 69 in St. Paul's Churchyard, London
people: Pamela; Pamela's father; Sir Simon Darnford; Mr. B
source: Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

label: Plate 9
transcription: The Marriage Ceremony performed in Mr. B's own Chapel by Mr. William's, Mr. Peters giving her away, Mrs. Jewkes waits behind Pamela, & the Maid keeps the door.
publication_place: No. 69 in St. Paul's Churchyard, London
people: Pamela; Mr. B; Mr. Williams; Mr. Peters; Mrs. Jewkes; Maid
source: Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

label: Plate 11
transcription: Pamela asking the blessings of Sir Jacob Swinford, Mr. B.'s Unkle, a rough old Fox-hunter, who after the most obstinate resolution to the contrary, relents, and becomes her great admirer. Mr. B. behind whispering Lady Davers, she now having conceived the highest esteem for her new Sister. The Countess Lady Davers, & his Nephew being present.
publication_place: No. 69 in St. Paul's Churchyard, London
people: Pamela; Sir Jacob Swinford; Lady Davers; Mr. B; Countess Lady Davers; Lady Daver's nephew
source: Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

label: Plate 12
transcription: Pamela with her Children and Miss Goodwin to whom she is telling her Nursery Tales. This last Piece leaves her in full possession of thepeaceable fruits of her Virtue, long after having surmounted all the difficulties it had been exposed to.
publication_place: No. 69 in St. Paul's Churchyard, London
source: Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

label: Title Page
transcription: Pamela Censured: In a Letter to the Editor: Shewing That under the Specious Pretence of Cultivating the Principles of Virtue in the Minds of the Youth of both Sexes, the most artful and alluring amorous ideas are convey'd. And that, instead of being diverted of all Images that tend to inflame, the Letters abound with Incidents, which must necessarily raise, in the unwary Youth that read them, Emotions far distant from the Principles of Virtue. Exemplified in many Quotations, with a Critical Review, and Remarks upon the Whole.
source: Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

label: Front board
source: Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

label: Back board
source: Rare Book & Manuscript Library, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

label: Plate 1 (1762)
transcription: Pamela is represented in this first Piece, writing in her late Lady’s dressing room, her History being known only by her letters. She is here surprised by Mr. B. who improves this occasion to further his designs.

label: Plate 2 (1762)
transcription: Mr. B. expostulating with Pamela in the Summer house after some liberties taken. Mrs. Jervis (who is seen through the Window) having just left her.

label: Plate 3 (1762)
transcription: Pamela swooning, after having discovered Mr. B. in the closet. He (frighted) endeavouring to recover her. Mrs. Jervis wringing her hands, and screaming.

label: Plate 4 (1762)
transcription: Pamela having divided her Clothes into three Bundles, in order to leave the House, rejects that containing her Masters presents, calling it the wicked bundle, & harangues over her own little Parcel, which she huggs in her arms; this occasions an exclamation from Mrs. Jervis: Mr. B. in ye Closet.

label: Plate 5 (1762)
transcription: Pamela setting out in the travelling Chariot (for her Father’s, as she is made to believe) takes her farewel of Mrs. Jervis, and the other servants; Mr. B. observing her from the window; by whose private order she is carried into Lincolnshire.
people: Pamela; Mr. B; Mrs. Jervis; servants

label: Plate 6 (1762)
transcription: Pamela, being now in the custody of Mrs. Jewkes, seizes an occasion (as they are walking in the garden) to propose a correspondence with Mr. Williams, in order to contrive an Escape, who agree to hide their letters between two tiles near the Sunflower.

label: Plate 7 (1762)
transcription: Pamela undressing herself (Mrs. Jewkes being first got to bed) while Mr. B. disguised in the maids clothes, with the apron thrown over his face, is impatiently waiting for the execution of his plot.

label: Plate 8 (1762)
transcription: Pamela on her knees before her Father, whom she had discovered behind the door, having overturn’d the card-table in her way. Sr. Simon Darnford, his Lady &c. observing her with eagerness and admiration. Mr. B. struck with this Scene is waiting the Issue.
people: Pamela; Pamela's father; Sir Simon Darnford; Mr. B

label: Plate 9 (1762)
transcription: The mariage Ceremony performed in Mr. B.’s own Chappel by Mr. Williams, Mr. Peters giving her away, Mrs. Jewkes waits behind Pamela and the Maid keeps the door.
people: Pamela; Mr. B; Mr. Williams, Mr. Peters; Mrs. Jewkes; Maid

label: Plate 10 (1762)
transcription: Pamela dressed in order to Mr. B. at Sr. Simon Darford’s, is prevented by the sudden arrival of Lady Davers, who forcibly detains her, & loads her with bitterest reproaches that rage & disdain could suggest. her Nephew is looking over Mr. B.’s letter in her hand, Jewkes and the Lady’s woman burst into the room to prevent mischeif, Colebrand is seen through ye. window.
people: Pamela; Lady Davers; Mrs. Jewkes; Lady Daver's nephew

label: Plate 11 (1762)
transcription: Pamela asking the blessing of Sr. Jacob Swinford, Mr B.’s Unkle, a rough old Fox-hunter, who after the most obstinate resolution to the contrary, relents, and becomes her great admirer. Mr. B. behind, whispering Lady Davers she now having conceived the highest esteem for her new Sister. The Countess, Lord Davers and his nephew being present.
people: Pamela; Sir Jacob Swinford; Lady Davers; Mr. B; Countess Lady Davers; Lady Daver's nephew

label: Plate 12 (1762)
transcription: Pamela with her Children and Miss Goodwin to whom she is telling her nursery tales. This last Piece leaves her in full possession of the peaceable fruits of her Virtue long after having surmounted all of the difficulties It had been exposed to.
